metadata.category: Building a Haptic Feedback App with CoreHaptics
metadata.title: Accessibility Considerations

inlineContent.text: Design inclusive haptic experiences for all users
and learn how to respect system accessibility settings.
Haptics are a double-edged sword in terms of accessibility.
Helpful cases:
Provides additional feedback channel for visually impaired
Alternative notification method for hearing impaired
Cases requiring caution:
Can be uncomfortable or painful for some users
Potential interference with assistive devices
Need to consider hypersensitivity or certain conditions
Check system haptic settings.
If the user has disabled haptics system-wide,
you should respect that.
Provide in-app haptic settings option.
Give choices like completely off, intensity adjustment, etc.
Provide visual alternative feedback when haptics are disabled.
Use screen flashing or highlight effects instead of vibration.
Design haptics that work with VoiceOver.
Provide additional voice guidance for VoiceOver users.
Build a multimodal feedback system.
Select appropriate channels based on user settings.
For users who cannot use haptics,
you must provide equivalent information in other ways.
Visual feedback (animation, color change)
Auditory feedback (sound effects)
VoiceOver announcements
Some users may be hypersensitive to vibration.
Tactile hypersensitivity
Certain conditions (Parkinson’s disease, etc.)
Pregnant women or those with heart conditions
Users who simply dislike vibration
Provide thoughtful options for them.
Provide an intensity adjustment slider.
Fine-tune within the app separate from system settings.
Allow selectively turning off haptics by situation.
Provide options like keeping only essential alerts and turning off the rest.
Ask about haptic preferences during onboarding.
Let users choose on first run.
Test that accessibility features work properly
in various scenarios.
Test while changing system accessibility settings.
Check various combinations like haptics off, screen reading, etc.
Verify with Accessibility Inspector.
Check that UI elements have appropriate accessibility labels.
The complete accessibility-supporting haptic system.
Verify the inclusive design for all users.
When a user has disabled haptics in system settings,
how should the app behave?
Respect system settings and don’t play haptics,
providing alternative feedback when needed
Respecting user’s explicit choice
is the basic principle of accessibility.
Play important haptics as exceptions
“Importance” is the app developer’s judgment,
not the user’s need.
Guide the user to turn it back on in app settings
Inducing users to bypass system settings
is not good UX.
Which is NOT an appropriate alternative feedback
for users who cannot use haptics?
Visual animation
Visual feedback is an effective substitute.
Essential feedback for screen reader users.
VoiceOver announcement
If the information haptics conveyed disappears completely,
it creates a gap in user experience.
Provide no feedback at all

and maintain app performance with efficient haptic implementation.
